headline: Grilled Stuffed Flank Steak With Salami, Fontina, Parmesan, and Bread Crumbs Recipe
description: Two cheeses, salami, scallions, and bread crumbs are all rolled tightly inside a flank steak, which is then cut into pinwheels and grilled until charred on the outside and medium-rare and tender in the middle.
name: Grilled Stuffed Flank Steak With Salami, Fontina, Parmesan, and Bread Crumbs Recipe
recipeIngredient: 4 ounces thinly sliced salami, cut into 1/4-inch-wide matchsticks
8 ounces Italian Fontina, cut into 1/4-inch cubes
1 whole flank steak, 2 to 2 1/2 pounds, trimmed of excess fat
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper

recipeInstructions.text: In a medium bowl, combine the garlic, scallions, parsley, salami, Fontina, Parmigiano, and bread crumbs and mix well. Add 1/4 cup of the olive oil and mix well with your hands or a spoon. Set aside.

Lay steak on a cutting board with grain running parallel to the edge of the counter. Trim left and right edges to form a clean rectangle and reserve scraps for another use. Hold steak flat with your non-knife hand and, with a sharp boning knife, carefully butterfly the steak, leaving the back edge attached by 1/2- to 1/4-inch of meat. Open up steak and flatten the seam gently with your hand to form a large perfect rectangle.

Season steak on exposed side with salt and pepper. Spread the breadcrumb mixture evenly over the beef, leaving a 1/2-inch border along the side furthest from you; press and gently pack the stuffing mixture onto the beef to keep it in place. Starting from the side nearest to you, roll up the meat like a jelly roll, pressing any stuffing that falls out of the ends back into the roll.

Tie the beef tightly with twine, spacing the ties evenly every 1 1/2 inches. Insert a skewer through each piece of twine. Using a sharp knife, carefully cut between the ties to make the pinwheels. Season with salt and pepper.

Light one chimney full of charcoal. When all the charcoal is lit and covered with gray ash, pour out and spread the coals evenly over half of coal grate. Alternatively, set half the burners of a gas grill to high heat. Set cooking grate in place, cover grill and allow to preheat for 5 minutes. Clean and oil the grilling grate. Place the pinwheels on the hot side of the grill and cook without moving until well charred on first side, about 3 minutes. Flip steaks and char second side, about 3 minutes longer. Transfer to cooler side of grill, cover, and cook until an instant read thermometer inserted into the center registers 120°F for medium-rare or 130°F for medium. Transfer to a platter, let rest for five minutes, and serve.

review.reviewBody:
Hnmm, I never thought of pinwheel slicing before the cooking. But I love the twist of these done on the grill!
I have always seared the whole stuffed piece, then braised it for 3-4 hours in tomato sauce. I make more of an Italian filling with rosemary, thyme, parsley, parmesan, either bacon or prosciutto, and hard boiled EGGS!!! Then, slice when done. So good!

I made this recipe today. My butcher cut the flank steak so I had two pieces to work into the roll. Also, my butterfly technique isn't that great. So I tied the whole thing tight, and I'm cooking the whole thing in the oven now without cutting into pinwheels. Kind of a variation, but we'll see how it works.
Don't Burn The Garlic's link is to a sex site. Either s/he's a spammer, or the site's been hacked.
@gravity- dont grill on foil causes alzheimers

I made this Saturday for guests. Really good. Moist and flavorful. 

Two things... I marinated the flank steak overnight in some olive oil, garlic, lemon juice, salt & pepper and it helped a lot with tenderness and flavor. Secondly, as mentioned prior to this, it's pretty messy on the grill. It didn't leak or open up on the circumference but on the cut edges. Even though I oiled down the grates, it stuck to the grill quite a bit. Did I have it overstuffed? Dunno, maybe, but it sure tasted good and didn't overpower the beef. Anyway..... if I were to do it again, I would do in on foil.... made a mess of the grill and lost a bit of food too. Great recipe though!

item.name: Grilled Stuffed Flank Steak With Salami, Fontina, Parmesan, and Bread Crumbs Recipe
